reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s opening analogies (flight, evolution) used to motivate the idea that narrow targets can still be hit via optimization. That point is somewhat relevant but not central to the essay’s main argumentative structure, which later separately assesses WAM-convergence, partial convergence + trade, and blockers; undermining the analogy doesn’t substantially undermine the later case (centrality ~0.2). As a refutation of the analogy’s evidential force, the critique has some bite—selection-driven convergence doesn’t straightforwardly support ethical convergence absent analogous feedback—but the essay itself explicitly discusses the absence of shared feedback/selection and does not heavily lean on the analogy thereafter, so the net weakening is modest (strength ~0.3). Most claims in the critique are accurate: the analogy’s success conditions involve strong external criteria and incremental feedback, which ethics may lack; and the analogy can risk smuggling in a shared optimizing criterion. The one overreach is implying the essay ‘still relies’ on that motivational pull as a key support rather than a scene-setting possibility (correctness ~0.85). The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little filler.
title: Analogies to flight and evolution fail without comparable selection pressure
